section.title: Unit: Concept of Energy
section.para: Key concepts:

list.item: We need energy for everything we do
We need energy to do work
Words associated with energy are-force

section.para: -power
-movement
-food( exercises) etc
Energy is the ability to do work.
Work means moving something,lifting something,warming something and lighting something.

list.item: Energy is one of the fundamental parts of our universe.
We use energy to do work.
Energy light our cities.
Energy powers our vehicles, trains, planes and rockets.
It warms our homes, cooks our foods, play our music.
It also give pictures to on television.
Energy powers machinery in factories and tractors on a farm.
Energy from the sun gives us light during the day.
It dries our clothes when they are hanging outside on a clothes line.
It helps plats grow.
Energy stored in plants is eaten by animals, giving them energy.
A predator animal eat their prey, which gives the predator animal energy.
Everything we do is connected to energy in one way or another.
When we eat ,our bodies transform the energy stored in the food into energy to do work.
When we run or walk , we burn food energy in our bodies.
When we think or read or write, we are also using energy
Many times its really hard work.
Cars, planes, light bulbs, boats and machinery also transforms energy into work.

section.para: Pic below

section.title: Activity
section.para: In our daily lives there are many things that we do that needs energy. As we get energy from food it is important for us to eat breakfast because that is where we get energy from. By just a movement we are using energy and in this picture some people are carrying some boxes so by doing so they are using energy.There is also different kinds of energy in this picture .

Learners needs to know all these different kinds. There are bicycles, motor cars, motor bikes and aeroplane and all these kinds of transport need energy to move. Also there is an electric lights on the streets and they use energy to make the light. There are many activities that is happening in this town, first of all there is no doubt that the weather is clear because there is someone on top of the roof is his baking himself on the sun which give him energy.

Learners divide yourselves in groups of six and go outside to play a game called-"Hide and Seek". Return to class after fifteen minutes and give a report back about how you feel. Each group must choose a leader who will give you proper instructions of what must be done. Also when you come to class you report back. At the end of the day you will be running and get tired, it is then you can realise that energy is the ability to do work. This game will be integration of Life Orientation with Natural Sciences.
Fig: 1

para.emphasis: Start this part of the work with a whole class discussion

list.item: Why do we need energy?
Where do you get your energy?
What other things have energy? (other animals,plants, machines, houses and cars)
Where do these things get their energy from?
What would happen without these sources of energy?

section.para: The much of the food that we gain from food is stored in fruits and vegetables in the form of glucose and starch. Fruit seeds and roots can be tested with chemicals to find out if they contain glucose and starch.

para.emphasis: Draw pictures to show how to do these tests

list.item: Take some food(e.g potato and cut it open on a dish)
Put a few drops of iodine solution on the food.
If the colour of iodine changes from yellow to black then STARCH is present in the food.
Take some food (e.g banana and cut it into small pieces.
Put it into a test tube and half fill the tube with BENEDICT'S solution.
Heat the tube in a beaker of boiling water.
If the Benedict's solution changes colour from blue to red then GLUCOSE is present in food.

section.para: Tswanelo and Mawethu tested seven different kinds of food for starch and glucose. They recoded the results of their experiments into a table.
They then use the results to try to make conclusions about how energy was being stored in these foods.
Try to help Tswanelo and Mawethu by writing your conclusions into the table below:

para.emphasis: Food tested Is glucose Is starch Part of

section.title: Unit: Renewable and non-renewable sources of energy

list.item: Renewable
Non-renewable
Resources
Nuclear
Geothermal
Hydroelectric power stations

section.para: Renewable resources are the resources that can be used again such as water, wind, solar, biomass and geothermal. Whereas non- renewable resources are those that cannot be used again such as natural gas, nuclear energy,coal and oil. Coal, oil and gas are called fossil fuels because they have been formed from the organic remains of prehistoric plants and animals.

Coal, oil and gas are fossil fuels. They have been made from plants and animals that lived on earth about 100 million years ago. South Africa has very large areas of coal underground in KwaZulu Natal and an oil ring in Mossel Bay.Fossil can be burned in power stations to produce electricity. It can be used in cars and planes for transport.

South Africa also has a large reserves of uranium which are used in Koeberg nuclear power station. This power station produces electricity without smoke pollution. Sun, wind and water can be used as sources of energy. Solar panels can be fitted to houses but this source of renewable energy is only available on sunny days.Wind energy can be collected through a windmill or wind -turbine which can be big and noisy. Hydroelectric power stations harness the energy in water stored in high dams. It is only possible in areas where there are high mountains and rivers.

section.title: What does renewable and non-renewable mean?
section.para: Complete the table below:

list.item: What is renewable and non-renewable resources?
Where do you find renewable resources?
What are the advantages and disadvantages of renewable resources?
Why do we find renewable resources?
How coal was formed?
How crude oil was formed?
Why do we need backup electricity supply if we have power failor?
Which city in South Africa does have more wind?
Why do we need a backup power supply when using solar system?
Debate on the advantages and disadvantages of nuclear energy.

section.para: Give the definition of renewable and non-renewable and give an example.
Integration with Social Science Resources (NS LO 3)

section.title: Unit: Different forms of energy
section.para: Key concepts:

list.item: Power
Force
Potential energy
Kinetic energy

section.title: Potential energy
section.para: Stored energy. An example is the elastic band.

section.title: Activity
section.para: In class learners need to some movements such as moving to and from the class. Again games are more important when dealing with kinetic energy. They must know that kinetic energy is about movement. Learners must also know the difference between energy , force and power.

section.title: Unit: Light Energy
section.para: Key concepts:

list.item: Sun
Coal
Paraffin
Candle
Wood

section.title: Energy we can see
section.para: Dark room, light a match.
Sources: coal, paraffin, candle and sun.

section.title: Activity
section.para: Learners need to be divided in groups of six and they must do a play of how to make a fire using the given material like candle, matches etc
Draw an energy flow diagrams for each of the following

list.item: An electric lamp, where electrical energy is converted to light energy and heat energy.

entry.para: 2. A television, where electrical energy is converted to sound energy, light and heat energy.
3. A car where chemical energy is converted to motion energy, sound energy and heat energy.

list.item: Anything that gives light is called a light source.
The sun is a light source.
Stars are light source.
A fire is light source.
A candle is a light source.
An electric bulb is a light source.
We see an object when they reflect light rays into our eyes.
We see the moon when it reflects light from the sun.
When we look in a mirror we see an image of ourselves reflected back.
Motor car headlamps give straight beans of light.
Light travel more quickly than sound.

section.title: Unit: Heat Energy - Energy we can feel
section.para: RECAP: Write your own definition of Energy:
Key concepts:
· Heat that does work is called HEAT ENERGY.
· Did you know? Thermos means heat in Latin.
· What do you think Thermal Energy is?
This is the word that scientists use for HEAT ENERGY.

section.title: Activity - Sources of heat energy
section.para: Heat energy can be found in many different places. Look at the pictures of some sources of heat energy. Can you recognize what heat energy each picture shows
Can you think of any other sources of heat energy from everyday life? Add two of your own into the blank blocks above.

Talk about this with your partner.You can write down your thoughts here before we discuss this in our next lesson.

section.title: Unit: Electrical Energy
section.para: Key concepts:

list.item: movement of electricity
Helps us to do work for many different things.

section.title: Sources of electricalenergy[ae]

list.item: Electrical energy is found all around us in the form of

section.para: lightening
static electricity on your clothes or your hair

list.item: People also make electrical energy from other energy sources:

section.para: Solar panels in the sun
Coal and Nuclear power stations
Wind power stations
Water (Hydro electric) power stations
Batteries

section.title: Uses of electricity

para.emphasis: Many items we use or see around us every day, are built to use electricity so that they can do work for us.

section.para: Use the space below to list as many items around your school that use electrical energy to do something. In the second column, write what work they do for us.

section.title: Electricity's quest for the ground
section.para: We now realise that we use electricity for many important things every day
BUT we also need to know that electricty always wants to get to the ground!
Sometimes it may try to go through you to get to the ground.
This will give you an electric shock.
A large electric shock can hurt you badly
It can even kill you, so it is important that we know how to use electricity safely.

1. ALWAYS turn off appliances and the wall switch before taking out or putting in plugs. Never pull out or put in a plug to a socket while the switch is still on. You could get a shock or blow the plug.
4. Never use an appliance that has a cord that is broken or has some of the metal wire showing.

2.Never use electrical appliances outdoors in wet weather or if you are wet. Electricity is attracted to water, so you WILL get a shock if you are touching an applicance and water drips into the socket, cord or motor.

para.emphasis: 8. Ask an adult to check what you are about to do is safe, before using an electrical appliance.

section.para: 3. Electricity can flow from one person to the next. NEVER try to pull someone who is being shocked away from the appliance. you will get shocked too! Use a non plastic/non metal object to separate them from the electrical source.
5. Never play near to or on electric fences or power lines. These both have live electricty running through it so you do not need to be touching it to get a shock!

6. Never put lots of applicances into one socket. Too much electricty flowing to one plug is dangerous. One multiplug adapter is safe, but do not put adapters into each other. Rather use 2 different plug points.
7. Do not play outside when there is thunder and lightening. If this powerful natural electricity strikes close to you, it will try to get to the ground through you!
8. Never use electrical appliances in the bathroom. Remember, electricity flows through water.
9. Wear shoes when using electrical appliances. Never use electrical appliances barefoot.
10...Turn off all switches after a power failure. When the power is turned on again, the sudden flow of electricity to all your appliances could cause them to blow.
Look at the picture below. People in Staticville use elctricity every day in their daily lives.
1. Circle 5 people who are making choices about how they use electricty that might put them in danger?
2. In the space below, write down what each one is doing that is putting them in danger:
3. Pretend that YOU and your friends are in similar situations.
a. In groups of 3/4, make up a role play to show your class how you would put your safety first for these 5 things.
b. come up with a short, catchy jingle to educate others about
-the dangers of electricty
-how you can use it safely
c. present this to your class and to a group of Grade 1s or 2s
Questions

section.title: Unit 2.8: Energy Systems
section.para: What is a system?
Key concepts:

list.item: When things work together for a specific reason, is called a system.
In nature, systems are found all around us.
People also invent systems all the time, to help them to accomplish something.

section.para: Energy Systems

list.item: When ENERGY is being released or stored from one step to the next, this system is called an ENERGY system

section.para: Bending and stretching
Things that can be bent or stretched, then released, show energy that is stored then released.
Rubber bands are excellent examples of how energy is stored and released by stretching.
Activity
1. Use a rubber band to show your desk partner when energy is stored and when it is released.
2. Have a class competition outside, to see who can shoot their band the furthest.
3. After the competition, choose the correct answer:
A. The winner was the person who managed to shoot their band the furthest.
B. The winner was the person who managed to release the most energy from their band
C The winner was the person who managed to store the most energy by stretching, before shooting it.
D All of the above
ANSWER - D all of the above
Falling
Things that fall show energy that is stored then released.
The water in a dam is another example of energy that is stored then released.
When the flood gates are opened, the water in the dam moves through the gates and falls down to the river below.
The water helps to show us how the energy is at first stored in the dam, then as the water falls, we can see that the energy is released.
Lets take a closer look at another example of a simple ENERGY system:
Draw pictures to represent each step in this energy system of the doorbell:
1. person uses his own energy to press the doorbell
2. this causes the electrical energy to flow to the doorbell box
3. this causes the gong to use energy to hit the metal of the bell
4. this causes the sound energy to be let off as a ringing sound
Therefore ,the doorbell rings (system)so that we can hear it to answer the door (reason).
Our bodies(system) produce energy so that we can live (reason).
Power stations(system) have many steps to produce electricity (reason).
The food chain(system) passes energy from the sun to living things so that each one can survive (reason).

section.title: Unit: Mechanisms in Machines (T)
section.para: Key concepts:

list.item: A mechanism is something used to help us move things and to do work.
A mechanism is made up of parts that fit together to allow movement.

section.para: Lets look at the mechanisms below:
Wheels and axles - An axle is a rod or bar that goes through the centre of a wheel. Wheels and axles usually work together. Wheels and axles lift or move a load.
A wagon wheel and axle. http://www.flickr.com/photos/oceanyamaha/180500640/
The front wheel and axle of a truck. http://www.flickr.com/photos/elsie/487841395/

Gears are wheels with teeth that move together. these are called cogs. Cogs fit into each other. This is called 'meshing together'. As one wheel moves, so the other follows. Each cog changes the direction of rotation from its partner cog.
A pulley is made up of wheels and a rope. These work together to raise, lower or move a load.
Pulleys used on a yacht to lift the sail. http://www.flickr.com/photos/uncle-leo/3172970451/
A very large pulley to lift a ramp to cross a river. http://www.flickr.com/photos/oddwick/1782228074/
Springs are coils that can be pressed down and released to cause movement
A spring in a wire fence. http://www.flickr.com/photos/dnet/5978602132/
A lever (bar) rests on top of a support (fulcrum) and lifts or moves loads.

section.title: Act[ap]ivity
section.para: Hinges are joints between 2 objects. They allow at least one of the objects to move.
A hinge on a door. http://www.flickr.com/photos/49889874@N05/4883527730/

section.title: Activity
section.para: Look at the pictures below. Each of these show technology mechanisms that make up a system. Can you recognize the mechanisms in each circles? There are 2 in each picture. Pics below
A Crane B Removal truck C windmill
D - Scissors
Extension - get a wow factor for mechanisms, these are more complicated mechanisms shown by moving pics - http://www.core77.com/blog/object_culture/gifs_that_explain_basic_mechanisms_1
Teachers guide
A Crane: lever and pulley
B Removal truck: lever, wheels and axles

C windmill: wheel and axle (there are, infact, also gears behind the wheel of the windmill, to change direction of the axle from vertical to horizontal movement. These can not be seen in the pic but this could be asked as extension to find the 3rd mechanism in this pic)
D - Scissors: Lever
Activity - Dismantling a moving toy
Bring an old toy from home that has a moving cmoponent to it that your gaurdians do not mind you taking apart.
Bring tools to carefully dismantle this toyIf you do not have one, ask your teacher to provide you with one for the next lesson.
Once you have taken it apart, can you identify the mechanisms inside that make this toy to move?
Description of toy:
Mechanisms:
Classify a classmate's toy mechanisms too

Mechanisms:
Activity Scavenger hunt

Upon returning to the classroom, they need to unscramble the code by making a sentence - then they know they have cracked it.
Questions

Look at it carefully .Can you circle and name them? (4 Marks)

section.title: Unit: Designing a moving object (T)
section.para: make an elastic band driven car
integrate Maths LO 3 - Design diagram ; side, front, back, underside view (incl axles)
Key concepts
* Energy transfer for movement of an object
*Finding solution to a problem using the design process

section.title: Setting[au]the scenario
section.para: Adam, Lerato, Yumnah and I love playing with toy cars. We enjoy running through the yard with them. Last year, Adam was in a bad accident which left him paralysed from the waist down. He still loves watching us play, and gets really excited when I choose one of his cars to race across the stoep. If his car beats the others', it just makes his day! I feel proud to use one of his cars, as he is a good friend of mine, and I know how much it means to him, but its not the same as him playing with us. I am sure there must be a way we can include Adam in playing with cars with us again. What could we make so we can once again all play with cars together?

section.title: 1. Br[av]ief
section.para: The children must design and make a car that can move on its own, so that Adam can still join in with the other children.
In your own words, write down what you are expected to do to solve the problem above

section.title: 2. Specifications
section.para: The solution to the problem must be: * a vehicle made out of recyclable
materials
* have 4 wheels
*2 external, removable axles each in an axle holder
*a spacer and stopper for each wheel
*move by the flow of energy from a stretched
elastic band

section.title: 3. Constraints
section.para: Use a selection of these materials:
Car construction: any recyclable materials
Sticking: masking tape, clear glue, Pritt or similar
Axles: skewer sticks, wooden dowls, lollipop sticks or similar
External axle holders: 2 clothes pegs for each holder
Wheels: polystyrene, jar caps, cotton reels, bottle tops or similar
Stoppers and Spacers: small pieces of rubber, plastic, putty, plasticine, prestik, elastic bands or similar

section.title: 4. Dreaming and Planning to make the vehicle
section.para: With the help of your teacher, dream up what your vehicle is going to look like!
Teachers' Guide thoughts -
Once kids have a picture in their head of what their car looks like, it makes it easier for some of them to plan.

After explaining the components the vehicle must include, and the examples of materials they can use, walk your class through a mental building exercise - allow them build up their car in their head, by your step-by-step mediation, before writing anything down.
1. each child to close their eyes, or put head on desk or have a pen and scrap paper in hand - depending on how best it helps them to visualise things

2. Once again walk the children through each component of their car, and give them options as you introduce each component and possible materials they could use, allowing them to make choices in their head of what they wish to use for their car.
Sentence starters like the following can assist you in this process:
*First, lets get an idea of the type of car you want to make - do you want a sedan or hatchback car [explain these words]? bus or minibus? tractor? bulldozer? open top?
- remember if you realise there is not a material that will make the shape you want, it is ok if this changes as we go through this mental building exercise

*Next, lets think about the body of our car - what is it going to be made of - an ice cream container, juice box, flora margarine container, a rounded coke bottle-type shape or anything else you can think of that would make an interesting body.

*Then, lets add some wheels to this body. Think about what type car you have chosen. Imagine what the wheels would look like. Now think about the size of the material you have chosen for your body. What wheels will be best - bottle tops, jar lids, polystyrene circles etc?

*The grip for your wheels is important too - depending on the use of your vehicle, how will your vehicle stick to the road? - sandpaper, matchsticks, rubber? ...or anything else you can think of that would make an interesting wheel with grip.
* What are you going to use for axles? - dowls, skewer sticks, sucker loillipop sticks?
* What are you going to use as spacers to separate the wheel from the body of your vehicle? - cork? small pieces of rubber? plastic? putty? plasticine? prestik? elastic bands?
*what are you going to use to prevent your wheels from falling off the end of the axle? - cork? small pieces of rubber? plastic? putty? plasticine? prestik? elastic bands?

*Finally, how are you going to add your own touch to this? - What colour is your vehicle going to be? How will you colour it - paint, paper covering, colour it in? Are you going to have any window? a number plate? lights? a tow bar? a bumper? - what will you make these from?
NB: to each question ALWAYS include "...or anything else you can think of that would make an interesting..[component]"

The potential danger of doing this mental exercise is that it could, and does for some children, stiffle creativity of those who are able to imagine their car without any mediation, by putting ideas of materials in their head. However, for those who begin designing without a mental picture and hence a peek over at their partner's ideas, this helps them to visualise where they are going.
Children who think best by writing down or drawing, could jot down ideas or shapes while being mediated through the "dreaming" process, instead of just closing their eyes.
Once you have a clear picture in your head of what your vehicle is going to look like, Complete the table to assist you in planning your vehicle:

entry.para: extra parts of choice - eg windscreen?
extra parts of choice - eg number plate?
extra parts of choice - eg exhaust?
extra parts of choice - eg lights?

section.title: 5.Designing the product
section.para: In the space below, draw a 2D design of your vehicle. Bear in mind the materials that you have chosen to use above when drawing.
*4x 2D colour views - side, front, back and underneath
*Label each part
*Label the materials to be used for each part
*Approximate measurements of the length and width of the vehicle rounded off to the nearest 5cm

section.title: Go through step 4 and 5 again to come up with a second design solution to thisproblem[ay]
6. Making the product
section.para: Now it is time to make your vehicle!
Follow the specifications carefully
Stick to the constraints closely
You can also use the rubric for the final product to check that you are meeting the criteria expected of you for solving this problem.
Enjoy!
